newsitem.title: USA: Report says blood pressure drug misused.
newsitem.headline: Report says blood pressure drug misused.

text.p: Doctors continue to administer an anti-high blood pressure drug in emergencies even though there is evidence it can backfire with deadly results, researchers said on Tuesday.

The report from Chaim Sheba Medical Centre in Tel-Hashomer, Israel, and the Oschner Clinic in New Orleans was based on a review of scientific literature involving the use of short-term nifedipine capsules.

Long-term, extended release forms of nifedipine and other long-acting forms of such drugs -- called calcium antagonists -- were not called into question by the study, published in this week's Journal of the American Medical Association.

Bayer Corp., which sells nifedipine capsules under the Adalat brand, disputed the study, saying labeling for the product already warns doctors not to use it in acute situations, and "far fewer" prescriptions have been written for it in the last few years.
The study published on Tuesday said however that short-acting nifedipine capsules continue to be a common treatment in emergency situations.
"Just because the practice of giving oral nifedipine capsules in hypertensive emergencies and pseudoemergencies is widespread and popular does not mean that it is safe and effective," the study said.
"To the contrary, serious -- even fatal -- adverse effects have been reported when the drug has been administered acutely for treatment of severe hypertension," it added.
The study said the short-term form of the drug can cause unpredictable falls in blood pressure, leading to stroke, heart attack and death.
